title: Grade 8
subject: Alternative Content Standards - English Language Arts (2017-)

document.title: ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR GRADE 8: ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTS

31A0CAF5EBFA4D83813208632D1C4F69.description:
Include multimedia
and visual information into
presentations.

138A651C8BBC44B783F92CB38622E865.description:
Select quotes
providing relevant information
about a topic from multiple print
or digital sources.

A450E3CE5CC64513B1CBE00D23B1E3BD.description:
Conduct short
research projects to answer and
pose questions based on one
source of information.

43C863A9E79A429FA9082E9364A233D0.description:
Use technology,
including the Internet, to
produce writing to interact and
collaborate with others.

D547277746D54E2F8EDFF4B6A4EF57F3.description:
The student can
identify a word that describes
feelings of people/characters in a
text or other sensory information
about a setting or event in a text.

292585F2ADD1405AB413F119FB1943A1.description:
The student can
identify words that describe the
feelings of people/characters in a
text or other sensory information
about a setting or event in a text.

F973D8DA6DF0463BAE17891EF3BAAAAC.description:
The student can
identify/use words to describe the
feelings of people/characters in a
text or other sensory information
about the setting.

1AEFD0E98E1D4C5EBF91B8267576634C.description:
Write about events
or personal experiences: Use
words that describe the feelings of
characters or provide other sensory
information about the setting,
experiences, or events.

A23F8C77654F427BA0877423B7E1B2A9.description:
The student can
select a fact or detail related to a
given topic.

B466B1AEEE874FC28753CE5502067043.description:
The student can
select facts or details related to a
given topic.

9F6192AD25D349F78705B94C3A716446.description:
The student can
identify/list/organize facts or details
to support a given topic.

861BEECB87AD4109B1BF0DC2FADD337E.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details: Write one or more facts or
details related to the topic.

7BF8C4BBABA54CEFA7862575A4731BC7.description: Students can investigate topics and present information.

38FC1FB5D5DB4A359E62CD00E02BE36C.description:
Use general academic
and domain-specific words and
phrases across contexts.

949E4A4A85274FA999E2CCE1A4DBE220.description:
The student can identify
the correct use of language to
communicate effectively with
familiar people (e.g., sharing
information, responding to
greetings, being polite, and making
simple requests, etc.).

FB77555604584CA59E4E4FBDE4F108A1.description:
The student can use
language to communicate
effectively with a variety of
audiences and for different
purposes (e.g., asking questions,
sharing information, responding to
greetings, using polite expressions,
using appropriate body language).

15960576F9AE4748968C55E53B00FD23.description:
The student can use
language to communicate
effectively with peers and adults
(e.g., asking and answering
questions, sharing information,
clarifying statements, making
requests, etc.).

C9092FCCD389406092D4569285630CA2.description:
Use language to
achieve desired outcomes when
communicating. A. Use to-be verbs
(am are, is was, were, be, become,
became) accurately when writing
and communicating.

05A47A4478294F648D64ED91B7153D2B.description:
Demonstrate
Standard English grammar and
usage when communicating: Use
appropriate verbs to match nouns.

7C07164C3EDF47C6B5FED87D0CE60710.description:
The student can
identify the action a person is taking
when given a picture prompt.

941821B537624152AC1054199EA33C6A.description:
The student can
identify appropriate past tense
verbs when communicating.

860C68E1A20E48BE91C7C7F93903B27F.description:
The student can
identify/use the appropriate verb
tense when communicating.

01A1B11C99914258B21254DEB4559AAA.description:
Demonstrate
Standard English grammar and
usage when communicating:
Form and use the simple verb tenses
(e.g., I walked, I walk, I will walk).

6D28481D24764AB693F269CFEA5C9C9D.description:
Adapt communication
to a variety of contexts and
tasks.

30D48BFBAEC647AA803EF359CFC933E7.description:
Present descriptions,
facts, or details supporting
specific points made on a topic.

287FE5B218324C858650B56403E01400.description:
The student can select
one or more details from
information presented orally or
through other media.

05577B0992F54B3EBE516959B20152CB.description:
The student can
identify one point that supports a
speaker’s argument (when the
argument is provided).

794132DA2C1D49ECBF3DF21EF0B93D5F.description:
The student can
identify an argument made by a
speaker and one point that
supports it.

BAA45B630459434182429AF67F8AF5D3.description:
Determine the
argument made by the speaker
on a topic.

6ECC687643DD4C8CA0BB5DE2290AD3CF.description:
Determine the
purpose of information
presented in graphic, oral, visual,
or multimodal formats.

73BF449493384967815FE9769DD7E9F0.description: Acknowledge new information expressed by others in a discussion and relate it to own ideas.

6FB5F6807CED4B34A23E1DEBC3D71AEE.description: Remain on the topic of the discussion when asking or answering questions or making other contributions to a discussion.

C205FF51F69449078E4F8A32AE01FCE4.description: Follow simple rules and carry out assigned roles during discussions.

9E83CB0DDB8E435BA658308481F24AFB.description: Come to discussions prepared to share information previously studied.

EE1D717E66D0430DBE2B8D459D338A33.description: Students can communicate for a range of purposes and audiences.

2BA662340BDC4CC69ECC63FB0F377A58.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions of
Standard English: Spell words
phonetically, drawing on knowledge
of letter-sound relationships and/or
common spelling patterns.

1D289D25837C411BBF70E20954164D61.description:
The student can
differentiate if a sentence is a
statement or a question.

BE1644BC390049C5AA243341FEBBAE15.description:
The student can
identify a sentence that uses the
correct capitalization or ending
punctuation.

0741E7AAFE234E23A7611180CF935130.description:
The student can
identify a grammatically correct
sentence that uses correct
capitalization and ending
punctuation.

6E94B7E13D734BC6A6CF6E27E60B9830.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions of
Standard English: Use end
punctuation and capitalization when
writing a sentence or question.

6BA2AE60B6DB41A1A01DF79196875734.description:
Write routinely for a
variety of tasks, purposes, and audiences.

E4A925EFA80C41EEB807E0DE5F1BC403.description: Apply Essential Elements of Grade 8 Reading Standards to informational texts (e.g., “Use relevant and sufficient evidence for supporting the claims and argument.”).

B87EF0C60D3843768A7F2BDA00C37426.description: Apply Essential Elements of Grade 8 Reading Standards to literature (e.g., “Compare and contrast themes, patterns of events, or characters across two or more stories or dramas.”).

AF285552A1C047AC971C381EDADB747B.description:
Use information from
literary and informational text to
support writing.

3D2FEA1C953E4311BC3955BA3EF094DF.description:
With guidance and
support from adults and peers,
plan before writing and revise
own writing.

B1861636661D4488A9F437293B80C48B.description:
Produce writing that
is appropriate for the task,
purpose, or audience.

E77BC6A074C149229300E85314F77574.description:
Write about
events or personal experiences.
C. Use temporal words (e.g., first,
then, next) to signal order. E. Provide
a closing.

36A0BB7806BC480E969BCBD1089A61F2.description: The student can provide a detail about a personal experience or other given topic while preparing to write/communicate about it.

5DB82A6C1AEF43EDAA6F209DF4EB3840.description: The student can write/dictate a sentence to express ideas about a personal experience or other given topic.

FED07ACBBF4E446E83884A3BE0DD6629.description: The student can write/draw/dictate about a personal experience, including three details about such things as people/characters, settings, and/or events.

B40F5BC71F6D49CF84A88EBCE66A7215.description: Write about events or personal experiences: Write a narrative about a real or imagined experience introducing the experience, at least one character, and two or more events.

FECE13DD4BE44A8DA79FA92B3861617D.description: Use domain-specific vocabulary related to the topic

FED110A1B84841A389133564BCB5F1BA.description: Introduce a topic clearly and write to convey ideas and information about it including visual, tactual, or multimedia information as appropriate.

C0177A09F39E421F98156832A2CBE7FB.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details:

4FC67D02BF86426287EDE6A07B5EE065.description: Write reasons to support a claim about a topic or text.

941B36CE7AEC4DF7B0D0D90D73CF81FB.description: Introduce the claim and provide reasons or pieces of evidence to support it.

36A9D22EBD9D4A8E8D72A1E3352BC397.description:
Write claims about
topics or texts.

1FF8A1E37DC44132800B8780D8886F86.description: Students can produce writing for a range of purposes and audiences.

D55CFC40D9D24CC0874F1014CCFDB5AC.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationships and use: Use
descriptive words to add meaning
when writing and communicating.

F8C6C1D5FB87414CA6202A7CF2991CD6.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationships and use: Use
knowledge of common words to
understand the meaning of
compound and complex words in
which they appear (e.g., birdhouse,
household).

741AF0CDBCBC4018A660CEA37540AD56.description:
The student can
identify the meaning of a word or
phrase used in context given choices
of words paired with
pictures/objects.

026C274739A94D9FA732189C18A8F5FC.description:
The student can
identify the meaning of a word when
presented in the context of a
sentence.

BCF04834F4E84BD2948BFBAC501F02B1.description:
The student can
identify the meaning of literal or
non-literal/figurative words or
phrases when presented in the
context of narrative or
informational text, including (but
not limited to) multiple-meaning
words.

18E9262CCC4F40E08B4145CE40FC0D85.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationships and use:
Demonstrate understanding of the
use of multiple-meaning words.

BF0BBC00F46144C3B8275D3CD7C6E514.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Seek clarification and meaning
support when unfamiliar words are
encountered while reading or
communicating.

4C39316DAC034BBB8E4782D455033951.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Use frequently occurring root
words (e.g., like) and the words that
result when affixes are added (e.g.,
liked, disliked, liking).

4BFB3193B7CF4397A73F0007BF582755.description:
The student can use
cues to recognize the meaning of
familiar words when paired with
pictures including (but not limited
to) content-area words.

F195653E440241958B636384056878D0.description:
The student can use
context clues to determine the
meaning of familiar words including
(but not limited to) content-area
words.

846C99B1E3C4456F93180585D14CE3E2.description:
The student can use
context as a clue to guide selection
of a word or words that best
completes a sentence including
(but not limited to) content-area
words.

60972B10D27A488A8E6CF6857FA98446.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Use context to determine which
word is missing from a content-area
text.

4F1C9B8176F547F99897C388B6D0FC2B.description:
Demonstrate
understanding while actively
reading or listening to literary
nonfiction.

4D14F449A0594D0AB33ED46C86A534C4.description:
Identify where two
different texts on the same
topic differ in their
interpretation of the details.

2FF877CD507F4B3195205C072C3E0AF2.description:
Determine the
argument made by an author in
an informational text.

D7BA576C5A9F40E6A382486F9484ACD6.description:
Determine whether
a topic is best presented as
audio, video, multimedia, or
text.

703DA58BA22141D38A8AF2D2B422963C.description:
The student can choose
the author’s purpose or point of
view when given choices.

3E7BE4A2E9434BF8974BC67068C0AA2B.description:
The student can
identify one example from a short
informational text that supports the
author’s purpose or point of view
(when the purpose or point of view
is provided).

F720AFF836E940CF87302A7A02EEECE7.description:
The student can
identify the author’s purpose or
point of view and/or select one
example from the text that
describes/supports it.

E1701CF34F0E4E65A425EFC0DEF804DC.description:
Determine an
author’s purpose or point of
view and identify examples
from text that describe or
support it.

F935CDF066AF4A298F3873A877DF74B7.description:
Locate the topic
sentence and supporting details
in a paragraph.

21542BF20D9B44598380ABD860680A57.description:
Determine
connotative meanings of words
and phrases in a text.

6A64E64B8A2D42A497C5AA1432AE550A.description:
The student can
identify which of two events/actions
came first in a short informational
text.

4EA7B560C1BE4DFDBE4049764B7455B2.description:
The student can put
two events from a short
informational text in order.

BF8FA86590484BCDA6E0AE29FDB58968.description:
The student can
correctly sequence three events
from an informational text.

6580E74EA86B4A9F8288FB1D34B84CCE.description:
Recount events in
the order they were presented
in the text.

8B7709EC27AF4C6C88065188FBB17F39.description:
The student can
identify the main idea of a short
informational text.

436441548E8A44ACA425D8369F4E22CB.description:
The student can
identify the main idea of a short
informational text.

13A8EE82C56946589D53341C4DA3725F.description:
The student can
identify a sentence/statement that
accurately summarizes a short
informational text.

95003B1B773D4D0DADF892887958FAFD.description:
Provide a summary
of a familiar informational text.

70555AE0D52B45E7B39400A27D582161.description:
The student can use
concrete details to answer simple
who, what, where, or when
questions about short informational
text.

BDF54A651D804DAFA201C246377FFB0E.description:
The student can use
concrete details to answer simple
questions and make predictions
about short informational text.

0B8F7E490E5C4A17A1F5E2D5EB8B1555.description:
The student can
answer questions about
informational text using explicit
details and/or identify specific
details that support an inference.

2B0CFB19A8464D649DE68299CCCC2903.description:
Cite text to support
inferences from informational
text.

36B0DF9CAC5E4366AD48B091090901B0.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of text while
actively engaged in reading or
listening to stories, dramas, and
poetry.

30236605A44546E3BA81319253FC25AE.description:
Compare and
contrast themes, patterns of
events, or characters across
two or more stories or dramas.

EAA9B33722BB4B0BA88F48ECE90104A4.description:
Compare and
contrast a text version of a
story, drama, or poem with an
audio, video, or live version of
the same text.

CEF47C7DD59B44DB831CF8468BCB2CC5.description:
Determine the
difference in the points of view
of a character and the audience
or reader in a text with
suspense or humor.

3D1ED3665CB5431D99104C4D0FC36136.description:
Compare and
contrast the structure of two or
more texts.

92A22056D5BB482B9E9C27B89C2DE350.description:
Determine
connotative meanings of words
and phrases in a text.

42B995D90A1A437FBE90DD72D870F243.description:
The student can
identify an event that occurred or a
character’s action in a short
narrative text.

9C9D62048E814F77B3E031803B6C1D4F.description:
The student can
select the action/event in a
narrative text that led to a later
action (when the later action is
given).

8D687AC5AAB54C89AD496DFD348500E6.description:
The student can
identify how a particular event in a
narrative text led to a later action or
caused a subsequent happening to
occur.

05C1966D422842CAB952C9D046408157.description:
Identify which
incidents in a story or drama
lead to subsequent action.

2CA9BFA6368549C2B91CD4E24E8A69B6.description:
The student can
identify the theme or main idea of a
short narrative text.

A01ABA2C97324142B4C2B6CD98F5E65C.description:
The student can
identify the theme or main idea of a
short narrative text.

8BBC98FEEB004002A10AEA3FBF1CF66C.description:
The student can relate
details about events, characters,
and/or settings to the theme or
main idea of a narrative text.

550E8CD56D064F27A0FA833A2D4CD824.description:
Recount an event
related to the theme or central
idea, including details about
character and setting.

15D6DB81638B450299077FFA7AF21490.description:
The student can use
concrete details to answer simple
who, what, where, or when
questions about short narrative
text.

E0D3EFA6627843D48408FCE62A419990.description:
The student can use
details from narrative text to
answer simple questions and make
predictions.

26E100F2EE9C4F04B7984BADB2ADCBA9.description:
The student can
answer questions about narrative
text using explicit details, and/or
identify specific details that support
an inference.

6246395F12674B79806B02DB671C9FB1.description:
Cite text to support
inferences from stories and
poems.

7CCF5777D04A4A8681C8327DBAEE4D4B.description: Students can comprehend text in increasingly complex ways.
